resources.string:
1 fluid ounce = 29.572 mL 
 1 cup = 8 fluid ounce 
 1 cup = 236.565 mL 
 1 quart = 32 fluid ounce 
 1 quart = 945 mL 
 1 L = 1.0567 quarts 
 1 L = 0.26417 gallons 
 1 gallon = 4 quarts 
 1 gallon = 3785 mL

10 mL = 1 cL 
 10 cL = 1 dL 
 10 dL = 1 L 
 10 L = 1 decaliter 
 10 decaliters = 1 hectoliter 
 10 hectoliters = 1 kiloliter

1 inch = 2.54 cm 
 1 mm = 0.03937 inches 
 1 cm = 0.01 m 
 1 m = 39.37 inches

1 g = 0.035273 avoidupois oz 
 1 g = approximately 1/28 oz 
 1 oz = 28.35 g 
 1 nanogram = 1 billionth of a g 
 1 avoidupois oz = 28.349527 g 
 1 avoidupois lb = 0.453592 kg 
 1000 g = 1 kg 
 1 kg = 2.20462 avoidupois lb

10 mg = 1 cg 
 10 cg = 1 dg 
 10 dg = 1000 mg 
 1000 mg = 1 g 
 10 g = 1 dg 
 10 dg = 1 hg 
 10 hg = 1000 g 
 1000 g = 1 kg 
 100 kg = 1 quintal 
 10 quintal = 1 ton

10 mm = 1 cm 
 10 cm = 1 dm 
 10 dm = 1000 mm 
 1000 mm = 1 m 
 10 m = 1 dm 
 10 dm = 1 hm 
 10 hm = 1000 m 
 1000 m = 1 km

100 sq. mm = 1 sq. cm 
 100 sq. cm = 1 sq. dm 
 10 sq. dm = 10,000 sq. cm 
 10,000 sq. cm = 1 sq. m 
 100 sq. m = 1 sq. dm 
 100 sq. dm = 1 sq. hm 
 100 sq. hm = 1 million sq. m 
 1 million sq. m = 1 sq. km

10 mL = 1 cubic centimeter 
 1,000 cubic millimeters = 1 cubic centimeter 
 1,000 cubic centimeters = 1 cubic decimeter 
 1,000 cubic decimeter = 1,000,000 cubic centimeters 
 1,000,000 cubic centimeters = 1 cubic meter
Association for the Advancement of Medical Instrumentation
Board of Nephrology Examiners - Nursing and Technology
Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services

An acronym that stands for the Advancement of Medical Instrumentation. AAMI creates the standards for varios features of dialysis, including water treatment and dialyzer reprocessing. The AAMI Guidelines have been approved by the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services.

A type of infection found under the skin, and resembles a blister or a pimple filled with pus or fluid. Infection on the fistula, graft or other tissues may happen if a fistula needle is used in or near the abscess.

An access is a route into the bloodstream which allows enough blood flow for hemodialysis. There are two types of access. Permanent Access is when the vein is connected to the artery by surgeon. It can be done directly through the fistula or synthetically with a piece of synthetic tubing, or graft. The temporay vascular access is performed by catheter when it is placed in a large central vein.
Aquired Immunodeficiency Syndrome is a disease that causes the body to loss control of the body\'s immune system, greatly increasing the chance for infections and other diseases such as cancer.
A type of kidney failure that happens suddenly. It is commonly caused by sickness, injury or toxic substances that create stress on the kidneys.
Tis Occurs when air bubbles get into the bloodstream and enters a vessels tiny enough to be blocked by air. The flow of blood becomes blocked when the air embolus in the vessels acts like a clot.
A blood protein. It is critical to pay attention to albumin levels, especially under 3.5g/dL. Patients with low albumin levels are malnourished.
A substance that has a pH level greater than 7.0

A colorless aluminum compound often found in water supplies to remove sediment and make water clearer. When such water is used for dialysis treatments, it is the key to keep the aluminum at low levels by treating the water used to make dialysate.
The spot where a surgical connection is made. An anastomosis is where vein and artery come together to form a fistula, or where an artificial vein is joined to the artery and vein for a graft.
The condition of having a low number of re blood cells. The results in weakness and weariness.
A localized enlargement of the artery caused by weakening in a blood vessels.
A blood thinner given to the patients during dialysis treatment to prevent clots in the blood.
A product that slows down and/or stops bacteria and viruses from growing and spreading.
This type of pressure is measured in the extracorporeal circuit between the arterial needle and the dialyzer.
A pressure sensor monitors pre-pump arterial pressures and post-pump arterial pressure.
AVF is a type of surgical connection made between the artery and the vein under the skin of a leg or arm to provide access to the blood.
The blood vessel that carries blood away from the heart during high pressure. Arteries help to bring oxygen to every part of the body through the blood.
Also known as continous cycling peritoneal dialysis . It is cycler machine used to do many exchanges of dialysate while the patient is asleep.

The movement of dialysate in the dialyzer membrane and its entry into the patients blood. It may occur when there is a change in the pressure or concentration gradient between the blood and dialysate.
A technique whee water is forced backwards through a filter to remove clogged particles in the water treatment system.
A one-celled microorganism that causes sickness and disease.
A substance with a pH of 7.0
A solution used by the body to neutralize acids that occur in the body when it breaks down protein and other types of food.
Happens when the semipermeable membrane of the dialyzer tears, allowing blood leak into dialysate.
This is an alarm system that is install on the hemodialysis delivery system, It alerts staff when a blood leak is occurring.
The extracorporeal circuit that carries blood from the patient through the arterial needle, to the dialyzer and back tot heir patient through the venous needle.
A pump that is part of the hemodialysis delivery system that pushes the patient\'s blood through the extracorporeal circuit at the fixed rate of speed.
A sturdy larger diameter section of the arterial blood tubing that is put through the rollers of the blood pump.
Also known as BUN. A method of measuring urea in the blood.
A pulse fekt in the antecubital area at the brachial artery.
a buzzing or swooshing sound that may occur by a high-pressure flow of blood through the patient\'s AV fistula.
A substance that stabilizes the pH level of a solution.
A technique where dialysis needles are placed in the fistula through the same hole ate the exact sanme angle.
A safety feature of the hemodialysis delivery system that ends the flows of fresh dialysateto the dialyzer and shunts it to the drain.
The chemical element used for nerve and muscle function. It is also helps form strong bones.
The act of putting dialysis needles into the graft or fistula.
The smallest blood vessels in the body where oxygenated blood crosses from the arteries to the veins.
A water treatment machine that has granular and is used to remove harmful substances from the water used for dialysis.
This happens when the heart stops beating.
A plastic tube that is usually place in the chest central vein.
A chemical element added to water to destroy microorganisms. Chlorine is removed from water used in a dialysis center with carbon tanks.
The loss of nephrones in a slow and long process. Kidney function is decreased when this disease occur.
The amount of blood(mL) that is cleared of solute in one minute of dialysis at the given blood and dialysate flow rate.
Recommendations from medical research and experts given to improve patient treatment results.
The fixed amount of fluid in the dialyzer machine removes from a patient\'s blood per hour under a specified pressure.
The ability of a fluid to transfer an electrical charge.
Yhe device checks the conductivity of the dialysate to ensure that is correct.
This is the action of blood moving in one direction and the dialysate moving in the other direction during treatment in the dialyzer.
The waste that is produced by muscle use and is removed by healthy kidneys through excretion in urination.
This is a urine test that determines if the kidneys are removing creatinine effectively from the blood in a certain amount of time.
When the blood cells shivel as a result of the blood cells being in contact with a solution that is more concentrated than the blood itself.
This process happens when the body does not have a sufficient amount of water.
This is a type of kidney disease that occurs because of diabetes.
A mixture of treated water and chemical used to remove waste from blood.
The procedure of removing waste and extra fluid from the blood of individuals with kidney failure
The state where extracellular fluid affects the patient\'s brain suddenly.
An artificial kidney used in hemodialysis patients with kidney failure to remove fluid and waste from the blood.
The pressure of blood against the arteries when the heart is at rest.
A chemical or process that eliminates or slows the growth of harmful microbes.
The information written down in a patient\'s medical record used to track patient\'s progress of treatment.
The patient\'s weight without excess fluid.
The amount of time a disinfectant must remian inside the dialyzer to ensure complete disinfection during reprocessing.
The act of having trouble breathing or shortness of breath.
A bruise or bleeding under the skin.
This is when water retention causes the body tissues to become swollen.
A compund that separates into ions when dissolved in water.
The amount of time that feed water must remian in contact with charcoal bed in a carbon tank during water treatment to remove chlorine and chloramines.
A change in the brain function that can be deadly.
The process where hormones are produced by healthy, functioning kidneys.
The toxic part of the cell wall in bacteria.
The networks created by the U.S. goverment in 1978 to ensure that dialysis centers provide patients the highest quality care.
The exterior part of the cells.
This means the outside of the body

The arterial bloodline, dialyzer, venous bloodline and the extracorporeal circuit monitors that extend out of the patient\'s body. It helps transport blood from access to dialyzer and back to the patient.
A device that includes a blood flow monitor, an air detector, a blood leak detector and an arterial pressure monitor that shuts off the blood pump in prevention manner.
A iron storage protein complex in the body\'s tissues usually measured with blood test.
A machine used to remove particles and other substances by preventing them from going through holes of different sizes.
A process of passing fluid through the filter.
Symptoms that happens shortly after initiaing a treatment with a new dialyzer. The following symptoms may occur: back pain, chest pain, nervousness, itchiness or heart palpitations.
This is a stream, for instance:blood flow is the stream of blood.
The amount of fluid that goes through a tube in a certain amount of time.
The speed in which fluid goes through a given lenght of tubing.
A trademark name for 37% solution of formaldehyde.
A difference , for intance, a concentration gradient is when the concentration of solutes with two fluids are separated by the semipermeable membrane.
The artificial peice of artificial vessel that is used to create a vascular access.
An alternate method, as opposed to chemicals, used to reprocess dialyzers and other equipments.
A measure of red blood cells.
A painful, hard, black, and blue collection of blood under the skin that occurs when there is a blood leak from the vessels that goes into the other tissues in the body.
The act of cleaning the blood of excess water and waste by using a dialyzer or artificial kidney.
The measurement of a dialysis dose to make sure that patients get the recommended amount of treatment necessary for survival.
A machine that is made up of a dialysate delivery system, safety monitors and a blood pump.
The red, oxygen-carrying pigment of all red blood cells.
A term that refers to a break or sudden burst of the red blood cells.
A blood thinner used in the dialysis to ensure that the blood flows through the extracorporeal circuit without any restriction.
This is a small tube extension from the blood tubing.
A pump made up of a piston, an electric motor and a syringe holder used to deliver exact amounts of heparin during dialysis.
The inflammation of the liver caused by the hepatitis viruses A, B and C.
Dialyzers are used during this form of dialysis treatment to remove more small solutes than convertional membranes.
A permeable membrane used to a broad range of molecular weight solutes.
An acronym that stands for the Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act. All patient\'s information must be kept confidential.
A dialyzer with a hollow-fiber design. It contains thousands of small hollow-fiber held in place at each end, and it is encased in a harp plastic cylinder.
A state of constant balance kept in the body.
A virus that disables the body\'s immune system by eliminating the white blood cells, and is transmitted through blodily fluids.
The water pressure naturally created or artificially created by a pump.
This state of having too much calcium in the blood.
This means high blood sugar level
This state of having too much potassium in the blood.
This state of having too much magnesium in the blood.
This state of having too much sodium in the blood.
This state of having too much phosphorous in the blood.
This state of having low level of potassium in the blood.
This state of having low level of sodium in the blood.
This state of having low level of phosphorous in the blood.
Dialysate that is diluted with excess amounts of water, which may cause hemolysis.
The condition that occurs when the body is attacked by bacteria, virus or any other disease causing organism.
Steps that are taken to put a stop to the spread of an infection.
An abnormal leakage of substances into the body\'s tissues.
When tissue is swollen due to an injury, surgery or infections.
This state where the body is lacks of iron to produce red blood cells.
Changes in a patient\'s blood urea level during a dialysis treatment.
The chemical process in which substance is broken down or created.
The smallest particle in a chemicla element.
This state of sickness or illness
This technique used with fistulae and grafts to prevent damage when needles are used too many times in the smae small area.
A licensed physician with a specialty in kidney disease.
A tiny blood purification filter in the composed of a tubule and glomerulus.
A sterile salt water solution containing 0.9% sodium chloride.
The movement of fluid across a semipermeable membrane from one area of lower solute concentration to an area with higher solute concentration.
This is the occasional strong hearbeat that can indicate cardiac arrhytmia.
A hormone created by the four parathyroid glands located in the neck.
An agent that causes sickness in humans.
This inflammation of the pericardium, a sack that eclose the heart.
This means allowing a substance to pass through.
The hydrogen ion concentration of a solution.
Drugs that binds with phosphorous in food so that phosphorous is not absorbed into the intestines.
A nonmetallic element found in meat, poultry, fish, nuts, peanuts, chocolate, colas and dairy products.
A metalic element and an essential electrolyte found in the human body.
The positive pressure after the blood pump and before the dialyzer.
This a measured between the patient\'s arterial needle and blood pump.
A force pressed against something in contact with an object.
This is when the bloodline and dialyzer are prepared for use by flushing them with normal saline.
This happens when the dialyzed blood that vcomes back to the patient through the venous needle is mixed with undialyzed blood exiting the arterial needle.
This happens when the immune system of the transplant patient attacks the transported organ becuase it is foreign to the body.
The process of cleaning and disinfecting the dialyzer and bloodlines, so that they may be used again by the same patient.
The membrane separation process for removing solutes from a solution.
The process of utilizing saline to flush the patient\'s blood back into the body after treatment.
This allows saline to be distributed to the patient during dialysis.
The material with microscopic openings or pores.
This is a tube that is placed into the body.
A chemical element and electrolyte found in the body.
A solution which is a combination of a solute and a fluid or a solvent.
A fluid where the substance were dissolved.
The narrowing of a blood vessel.
Small, expanding metal rings that are put inside a fistula or graft that the fistula or graft feeds into, to prevent the lumen from narrowing.
The state of being completely free of all living organism, such as bacteria.
The pressure found inside the arteries during a hearbeat.
This indicates if the dialysate temperature is too high or too low.
The vibration of the blood flow through the patients fistula or graft.
The process of injecting a drug to dissolve a thrombus
A clot formed inside a blood passage or a blood vessel.
Small plastic caps that contain filters and are used to keep fluid or blood from getting into the pressure monitors on the dialysis machines.
The average pressure minus the permeate pressure.
The rate in which fluid goes from the blood into the dialysate through the semipermeable membrane.
The build-up of waste in the blood that happens at the end of kidney failure.
This type of pressure measures the extracorporeal blood circuit pressure after the dialyzer and before the blood goes back into the patient\'s body.
An infective microorganism that lives off of other living cells.
This is used in water treatment to decrease the concentration of magnesium and calsium that form scale.
1. When was the first dialysis treatment done?
Dr. Willem Kolff is considered the father of dialysis constructed the first dialyzer (artificial kidney) in 1943.
2. What are the two main types of dialysis today?
a. Chronic Renal Dialysis and Early Renal Dialysis
b. Hemopobic Dialysis and Peritonic Dialysis
c. Filtration Dialysis and Osmosistonic Dialysis

The two types of dialysis are hemodialysis and peritoneal dialysis. \n Hemodialysis - artificial kidney is used to filter the waste and remove excess fluid from your blood. \n Peritoneal Dialysis - the blood is filtered and cleaned inside the body.
3. In Hemodialysis, what do you call the entry into patients bloodstream?

Vascular access - a flexible and sterile plastic tube called a catheter is inserted into a blood vessel to allow blood to be drawn or medication to be delivered to a patientâ€™s bloodstream over an extended period of time.
4. What statement is true about Dialysis Technician Professionalism?
a. Get to work on time.
c. Keeping your work station clean.
All of the above, all of the three choices are good practice as a professional Dialysis Technician.
5. What are the main functions of the the kidney that the Dialysis can replace?
b. Waste removal from the blood.
All of the above, all of the three choices are the functions of the kidney that the dialysis replaced during the patient\'s treatment .
6. Arrange the following in history order, 1-Kiil Dialyzer, 2-Shunt, 3-Kolff\'s rotating drum, 4-Arteriovenous fistula.
a. It\'s a catheter tube that is placed in the patient\'s abdomen.
b. It\'s a connection of the artery and vein inside patient\'s arm.
c. It\'s a plastic tube connection of the vein and artery outside the patient\'s skin.
d. It\'s a connection of the dialysis machine and the patient.
It\'s a plastic tube connection of the vein and artery OUTSIDE the patient\'s skin.
8. How does Medicare pay clinics for the dialysis treatment?

Section 1881 (b)(12) of the Social Security Act, as amended by section 623 of the Medicare Prescription Drug Improvement and Modernization Act of 2003, establishes the End Stage Renal Disease (ESRD) composite rate payment method for most dialysis related services provided by renal dialysis facilities to Medicare beneficiaries with end stage renal disease. -via cms.gov
9. Why is it preferred to use arteriovenous(AV) over shunt?
a. Shunt is more expensive than AV.
b. Shunt is high risk of infection.
Both 2nd and 3rd choices are correct , Shunt has a high risk of infection and clot compared to AV access.
10. What do we call the today\'s artificial kidney that is used in HD?

Dialyzer is an artificial kid that is use in dialysis with four major comparment. (1)Blood, (2)dialysate, (3)semipermeable membrane that separates blood and dialysate, and (4)Member support structure.
11. What kind of dialyzer do we use in HD?

Hollow fiber dialyzer is what they use on todays dialysis clinic that comes with different size such as 160, 180, 190, 200, and 250. It is used based on patient\'s compatibility and Doctor\'s prescription.
12. How many months of working experience do you need to have as adviced for you to take the certification exam?
It is advisable to have at least 6 months of working experience before taking the state test due of clinical and situational questions.
13. When behaving in a professional manner, which is NOT an action that illustrates a conscientious action?
a. Address patients by theit title.
b. Get your supply and equipment ready.
c. Keep your work station clean
d. Giving patients information about the othe patients.
As a professional Dialysis technician discussing patients informations to another patient is inappropriate and unprofessional.
14. When working with patients in a professional medical settings, What sort ofbounderies should be follow as a Dialysis Technician?
a. You should invite the patient to your place and offer food after the treatment.
b. You should not talk about your personal problem with your patient.
c. You can take gifts from the patient\'s only if there is appropriate occassion.
d. You can barrow money from the patient\'s as far as you pay it back on time.
The correct answer is B, all of the listed situation are bounderies between us and the patients and we shouldnt do any of those.
15. Elsa a lady Dialysis technician was asked by Mr O\'neal a patient to have a dinner with him at his place alone after her shift. What should Elsa do?
c. She shouldnt upset the patient and go with him on a dinner.
d. Inform all the staff members in case something bad happens.
The correct answer is A, any inappropriate act or behavior should be notify to the Social Worker, and the social worker should educate the patients on proper manner and act as a dialysis patient.
16. Select the main function of the kidney.
a. Clean and filter the blood.
All the following choice are the main function of the kidneys.
17. How many nephron are on each kidney?
There are 1,000,000 nephron in each human kidney.
18. What do you call the tiny blood vessels that carry the blood to each nephron?
Capillaries is the smallest blood vessels in the human body and loops that dip down into the medulla to carry the blood to each nephron.
19. What is the number one cause of Chronic Kidney Diseaese in United States?
The number one cause of kidney disease is Diabetes with approximately 44 percent of all kidney failure cases while High blood pressure with 28 percent and the rest sre from other complication.
20. What is the functional unit of the kidney called?
Nephron is the functional unit of the kidney. It is comprised of five different parts that all work together to help the kidney function properly.
21. What is the leading cause of anemia on ESRD?
Erythropoietin control the red blood cell production. Not enough production can cause anemia.
22. What is Nephron made uo of?
d. Loop of henle and bladder
Glomerulus is a part of the nephron where fluid is filtered from the blood and tubule is a long narrow tube where the filtered fluid from the Bowmanâ€™s capsule is processed and converted into urine
Although all four are type of dialysis, Hemodialysis is done In-Center with help of the nurse and technicians.
24. Which of the following is Peritoneal Dialysis treatment?
Two types of Peritoneal Dialysis Continuous Ambulatory Peritoneal Dialysis (CAPD) and Automated Peritoneal Dialysis (APD)
25. What does the endocrine function of the kidney do?
a. Make erythropoietin and an active form of vitamin D.
c. Makes protein and Vitamin D
d. Regulates red blood cell and urine.
It makes erythropoietin and produce an activated form of vitamin D.
26. Which of the following describes dry weight?
a. Weight of the patient before meals.
b. Weight of the patient between treatment.
c. Weight of the patient before treatement.
d. Weight of the patient after the treatment.
Dry weight is the ideal weight or the target weight of the patient which is mostly achieve after the dialysis treatment.
a. The law that protects patients health information.
b. The law that protects all health care professionals.
c. The law on how to treat patients.
d. Standard of the Dialysis treatment.
Summary of the HIPAA Privacy Rule for the patients.
28. Mr Waltz, 32 years old young patient, he is athletic and wishes to have his treatment shortened by 20 minutes today so he can play basketball. What is your response?
a. He can leave early since he looks fine.
b. He can leave early but he must make and sign a note.
c. Prescribe time must be done to avoid medical problem.
d. As per the center policy, patient are not allowed to discontinue the treatment early.

The answer is C, but in real life we cannot force patient to stay. The can leave as they want but you must educate the patient that it might harm them, notified the nurse and make them sign a AMA form.
29. Which of the following medical problems is a results of chronic kidney disease?
All of the listed medical problem can be occur due of chronic kidney disease.
30. Who is responsible for making the patients, patients family and friends can adjust to changes that may happen from a kidney failure?

All of the listed health care provider is responsible to educate the patient. While the social worker has most of the part, making sure that the family member and friends is also educated about the matter.
31. As a Dialysis Technician health care provider, What is your role in anemia management?
a. Advise patient to sleep early
b. Return as mush of the patient blood as you can at the end of each treatment.
c. Advise patient to eat more
d. Advise patient to drink more water.
At the end of the treatment make sure you return as mush blood as you can to the patient.
b. Over production of parathyroid hormones.
c. Red blood cell contain protein.
Pruritus simply means itching. It can be associated with a number of disorders, including dry skin, skin disease, pregnancy, and rarely, cancer.
c. Inflammation of membrane around the heart.
d. Protein deposited in the soft tissue, bones and joint.
Pericarditis (PER-i-kar-DI-tis) is a condition in which the membrane, or sac, around your heart is inflamed
34. What do you call the protein that the red blood cell contains?
Hemoglobin is the protein molecule in red blood cells that carries oxygen from the lungs to the body\'s tissues and returns carbon dioxide from the tissues back to the lungs.
a. Low Potassium in the blood.
b. Low Calcium in the blood.
c. High Potassium in the blood.
d. High Calcium in the blood.
Hyper mean high, and kalemia for potassium, it means above normal potassium.
37. Which of the following is considered a fluid?
Dialysis patients has fluid so its very important to educate them about fluid intakes. All of the following are considered as fluid.
38. Which of the following is high potassium food?
a. Anything that can hurt the patient.
b. Anything that the patient\'s eat and drink during the treatment.
c. Anything that is used to melt a substance.
d. Anything that can be melted by liquid.
Solute(solid) is anything that dissolves in a solvent(liquid).
40. What doyou call the mixture of solute and solvent?
Solution is a mixture of Solute(solid) and solvent(liquid).
41. Which of the following is the solute in the dialysate solution that is used during dialysis?
Dialysate solution is composed of bicarbonate(solid) and water(liquid).
42. Which of the following is the solute in the dialysate solution that is used during dialysis?
Dialysate is a mix ture of sodium, potassium, calcium, bicarbonate, magnesium, chloride, glucose which are electrolytes.
43. What do you call the filter that only allow certain size of particles to pass through?
Dialysate is a mix ture of sodium, potassium, calcium, bicarbonate, magnesium, chloride, glucose which are electrolytes.
44. What do you call the movements of particles from an area of higher concentration to the area of lower concentration?
Dialysate is a mix ture of sodium, potassium, calcium, bicarbonate, magnesium, chloride, glucose which are electrolytes.
45. When is the negative pressure created?
a. Negative pressure are created when the particles are pulled across the membranes.
b. Negative pressure are created when fluid is pulled through a restriction.
c. Negative pressure are created when particles are moving in the same directions.
d. Negative pressure are created when particles are moving on different directions.
Dialysate is a mix ture of sodium, potassium, calcium, bicarbonate, magnesium, chloride, glucose which are electrolytes.
46. What do you call the movement of solvent from an area of lower solute to the area of higher solute concentration?
Dialysate is a mix ture of sodium, potassium, calcium, bicarbonate, magnesium, chloride, glucose which are electrolytes.
47. Which of the following explains Hydraulic pressure?
a. This would cause a solution.
b. This would cause the solution to separate solute and solvent.
c. This would make circulation movement with the solution.
d. This would heat up the solution.
Dialysate is a mix ture of sodium, potassium, calcium, bicarbonate, magnesium, chloride, glucose which are electrolytes.
48. This is the movement of fluid to the filter, and traps the particles that is too large to pass through.
Dialysate is a mix ture of sodium, potassium, calcium, bicarbonate, magnesium, chloride, glucose which are electrolytes.
49. What do you call the removal of water from the blood?
Dialysate is a mix ture of sodium, potassium, calcium, bicarbonate, magnesium, chloride, glucose which are electrolytes.
50. What is the intravascular fluid compartment?
c. Blood inside the blood vessels.
Dialysate is a mix ture of sodium, potassium, calcium, bicarbonate, magnesium, chloride, glucose which are electrolytes.
51. What happens to the level of waste in the blood during dialysis?
Dialysate is a mix ture of sodium, potassium, calcium, bicarbonate, magnesium, chloride, glucose which are electrolytes.
52. Which of the following are the extracorporeal circuit?
Dialysate is a mix ture of sodium, potassium, calcium, bicarbonate, magnesium, chloride, glucose which are electrolytes.
53. What are the two compartment that each dialyzer has
Dialysate is a mix ture of sodium, potassium, calcium, bicarbonate, magnesium, chloride, glucose which are electrolytes.
Dialysate is a mix ture of sodium, potassium, calcium, bicarbonate, magnesium, chloride, glucose which are electrolytes.
55. Which are the characteristic of the dialyzer?
b. Molecular weight cut off and surface area.
c. Mass transfer coefficient and clearance.
Dialysate is a mix ture of sodium, potassium, calcium, bicarbonate, magnesium, chloride, glucose which are electrolytes.
56. Which is not characteristic of the dialyzer?
Dialysate is a mix ture of sodium, potassium, calcium, bicarbonate, magnesium, chloride, glucose which are electrolytes.
57. Which of the following is the way to removes solute?
Dialysate is a mix ture of sodium, potassium, calcium, bicarbonate, magnesium, chloride, glucose which are electrolytes.
58. What do you call the clear plastic cylinder that has a thousands of fiber tubes as thin as hair strands?
Dialysate is a mix ture of sodium, potassium, calcium, bicarbonate, magnesium, chloride, glucose which are electrolytes.
59. What kind of substance is removed by dialysate from the patient\'s blood?
Dialysate is a mix ture of sodium, potassium, calcium, bicarbonate, magnesium, chloride, glucose which are electrolytes.
60. What kind of substance is replaced by dialysate for the patient\'s body pH balance?
Dialysate is a mix ture of sodium, potassium, calcium, bicarbonate, magnesium, chloride, glucose which are electrolytes.
b. Total number of solution per liter.
d. Total elctric charge of a solution.
Dialysate is a mix ture of sodium, potassium, calcium, bicarbonate, magnesium, chloride, glucose which are electrolytes.
62. What happens when dialysate gets too hot?
Dialysate is a mix ture of sodium, potassium, calcium, bicarbonate, magnesium, chloride, glucose which are electrolytes.
63. Name two types of Ultrafiltration system:
a. Numeric UFR control and TMP flow control.
b. TMP control and flow rate control.
c. Flow control and volumetric UF control
d. System control and UFR control.
Dialysate is a mix ture of sodium, potassium, calcium, bicarbonate, magnesium, chloride, glucose which are electrolytes.
64. Which of the following is a component of extracorporeal circuit?
Dialysate is a mix ture of sodium, potassium, calcium, bicarbonate, magnesium, chloride, glucose which are electrolytes.
